content.html:
Although 2022 seems to have come and gone so fast that it barely even registered, when I look back at how I was feeling on this day last year it does feel as if things have actually changed quite a bit.

I started the year in Covid isolation, lying in bed watching all of the Karate Kid movies back-to-back, and we ended the year with a long-awaited holiday to New York, something that seemed impossible to contemplate a year or two ago. Although the pandemic is certainly not over (despite what the media and government might want us to believe), planning for the future is once again on the table.

2022 in review

With Covid restrictions pretty much universally lifted after the Christmas period, we made up for the lack of holidays since 2020 by taking three in 2022; firstly a few nights away in an original 1970s Volkswagen campervan, which was fun except for when you needed it to get up a steep hill; then a week on the Norfolk Broads in a fancy cruiser - relaxing until you had to manoeuvre through a narrow channel or into a tight berth; and finally the aforementioned week in New York, a long-postponed birthday treat for my wife. It's felt like I've had far more time-off this year than usual, although perhaps that is more a symptom of the previous two years' lack of opportunities to travel than anything else.

I was also able to go to live music again in 2022. I didn't get to see Foo Fighters as planned due to the untimely death of Taylor Hawkins, but I did see some of my other favourite bands and performers: Phoebe Bridgers, Bartees Strange, We Are Scientists, Gogol Bordello ... and, unplanned but a lifelong ambition, Guns N' Roses, who we watched from precariously high up in the stands at West Ham's stadium. It was definitely an experience, but I don't think I'll be too eager to see other stadium acts in the future - I'd rather be down the front in a much smaller crowd. 2023 is shaping up to be another gig-filled year too, with Metric, Iron Maiden and KISS already on the calendar.

Speaking of music and concerts, this year I joined the City of Peterborough Symphony Orchestra, a big step up in terms of challenge compared to the community orchestra I was playing with previously. With 3-4 concerts scheduled every year, I've had to step up my practice regime.

On the work front, I finally returned to Amsterdam, albeit only for a couple of nights. It was weird being back - I seem to have lost my affection for flying - and it remains to be seen how the company will adjust to a more hybrid home/office setup. I started working from a dedicated studio in the back garden during the summer (just in time for the hottest year on record, thank God for air conditioning!) which has really helped me to focus (and probably to talk to myself far too much).

The year ended in the worst way possible, however, when my father finally succumbed to the ill health brought about by multiple strokes he suffered in 2021. He died in November. Delivering his eulogy was one of the hardest things I've ever had to do.

2023 resolutions

Last year I only had one resolution, which was to start running again - which I did, averaging two runs per week if you ignore a bit of a summer lull. This year I'm stepping up the running even more, with two half-marathons booked in April and June.

For 2023, though, what do I want to change about myself? Spend more time working on this site, certainly, both writing and designing/coding; but I think the main alteration I should strive for, and one that has the potential to improve my overall wellbeing, is:

  1. Slow down and appreciate things more. I frequently find myself rushing through things as if I need to be done and move on to the next one as soon as humanly possible. I find I don't take the time to slow down and really consider my response to things, even when it's as unimportant and ephemeral as social media content. I want to try to appreciate things more, whether that's what I read, listen to, watch or engage with online.

name: My 2022 in books, films and music

content.html:
Year sixteen of sitting myself down in front of the computer on New Year's Eve and totting up (almost) everything I read, watched or listened to over the previous twelve months. (Not that you'd know, since I've nuked this blog's history several times over the last year or two, but it's all still there on archive.org if I ever want to remember or plot how my tastes have changed over the last decade-and-a-half.) I'm not even sure whether I enjoy this exercise any more, but it's been a thing for too long to give it up now.

Reading

I managed to read a couple more books this year than I did in 2021, although not through any deliberate effort. I still only ever really read in bed at the moment - perhaps if office-working does become more desirable I might read more while travelling as I did pre-pandemic, but I honestly don't see that situation changing any time soon.

Fiction

  • Imajica (Clive Barker)
  • Homeland (R.A. Salvatore)
  • To Have and Have Not (Ernest Hemingway)
  • Once Upon a Time in Hollywood (Quentin Tarantino)
  • Illuminations (Alan Moore)
  • On the Road (Jack Kerouac)
  • The White Tiger (Aravind Adiga)
  • Butcher's Crossing (John Williams)
  • World War Z: An Oral History of the Zombie War (Max Brooks)
  • Factotum (Charles Bukowski)
  • The Last Guardian (Jeff Grubb)
  • A Canticle For Leibowitz (Walter M. Miller Jr.)
  • The Moviegoer (Walker Percy)
  • Gardens of the Moon (Steven Erikson)
  • Murder on the Orient Express (Agatha Christie)
  • The Corrections (Jonathan Franzen)
  • No One Is Talking About This (Patricia Lockwood)
  • Harvest (Jim Crace)
  • Big Damn Hero (James Lovegrove)
  • Books of Blood: Volume One (Clive Barker)
  • Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell (Susanna Clarke)
  • The Big Six (Arthur Ransome)
  • Better than Life (Grant Naylor)
  • Infinity Welcomes Careful Drivers (Grant Naylor)
  • Someone Should Pay for Your Pain (Franz Nicolay)
  • Antkind (Charlie Kaufman)
  • Siddhartha (Hermann Hesse)

As usual, a mixture of classic and modern literature, with a few re-reads of old favourites sprinkled throughout. After watching the new Hellraiser film I ordered a couple of Clive Barker books that I never got around to reading as a younger fan, and also filled in some gaps in other favourite authors' works (Bukowksi's Factotum was excellent; Hemingway's To Have and Have Not was massively disappointing). Alan Moore's new book of short stories came out, and I read Agatha Christie for the first time, but I think my favourite book was probably Antkind by screenwriter Charlie Kaufman. It had a lot of the same elements found in several of his films (Anomalisa, Adaptation, Eternal Sunshine and Synecdoche New York) while creating something completely unique.

Non-fiction

  • The Story of the Oliver Twins (Chris Wilkins)
  • The Fry Chronicles (Stephen Fry)
  • I Am C-3PO: The Inside Story (Anthony Daniels)
  • How to Be an Imperfectionist: The New Way to Fearlessness, Confidence, and Freedom from Perfectionism (Stephen Guise)
  • Long Players: Writers on the Albums that Shaped Them (Tom Gatti)
  • Ramble Book (Adam Buxton)
  • You'll Die in Singapore (Charles McCormac)
  • Empire of Imagination: Gary Gygax and the Birth of Dungeons & Dragons (Michael Witwer)

Another mixture of autobiographies and histories. The D&D book was an interesting insight into the birth of the game, as was the story of early ZX Spectrum pioneers the Oliver Twins, but the book that I was most surprised to enjoy was You'll Die in Singapore, a real-life recounting of a Japanese POW escaping across Indonesia. I only picked it up because it came in a "surprise book" bundle from Etsy, but it was actually very readable.

Comics

  • Crossed + One Hundred, Volume 1 (Alan Moore)
  • Red Rackham's Treasure (Hergé)

Hardly worth mentioning this year, the only comics I read were Alan Moore's run on Crossed (which I didn't really know enough about to really enjoy) and a Tintin book.

Watching

As usual, I'm only listing the films that I saw for the first time in the past year.

  • Zodiac
  • The Pianist
  • Licorice Pizza
  • The Power of the Dog
  • The Door Into Summer
  • The Batman
  • Ghostbusters: Afterlife
  • Accident Man
  • All the President's Men
  • Rent
  • The Sparks Brothers
  • Short Term 12
  • 8½
  • Everything Everywhere All At Once
  • Thor: Love and Thunder
  • Hellraiser (2022)
  • Tenet
  • Clerks III
  • Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri
  • Metal Lords
  • A Christmas Story
  • Top Gun: Maverick
  • Uncharted
  • Black Panther: Wakanda Forever
  • Bill & Ted Face the Music

After months of anticipation, PT Anderson's latest film Licorice Pizza was finally released back in January, and while not as immediately memorable as Boogie Nights or Magnolia I still enjoyed it a lot. Edgar Wright's documentary about Sparks was excellent, despite only knowing a single song by the band; and as a lifelong Kevin Smith fan I loved Clerks III (but would probably not recommend it to anyone that isn't). However, the film I've been recommending to everyone since I saw it is Everything Everywhere All At Once - it's utterly unlike anything else you're going to see, and I'm unsurprised to see it on so many end of year lists.

Listening

As per usual, artists that released albums in the first half of the year are at something of an advantage - there were definitely better albums that came out in the latter half of 2022 that failed to make it into the top ten (also not helped by Spotify's scrobbling plugin occasionally not working).

Top artists listened to in 2022

  1. Post Malone
  2. Guns N' Roses
  3. Eddie Vedder
  4. Bloc Party
  5. Arcade Fire
  6. Pearl Jam
  7. Afghan Whigs
  8. Bartees Strange
  9. Muse
  10. Mitski

Fewer old favourites than last year, although Guns N' Roses are only so high up because I went to see them in concert back in July. Everyone else besides Pearl Jam had a new album out this year.

Top albums listened to in 2022

  1. Twelve Carat Toothache - Post Malone
  2. Earthling - Eddie Vedder
  3. Farm to Table - Bartees Strange
  4. Laurel Hell - Mitski
  5. Labyrinthitis - Destroyer
  6. Endless Rooms - Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever
  7. A Light For Attracting Attention - The Smile
  8. Raw Data Feel - Everything Everything
  9. Things Are Great - Band of Horses
  10. Quitters - Christian Lee Hutson

I wouldn't categorise myself as a fan of Post Malone particularly, but I did find myself returning to his new album several times throughout the year - it's an undemanding pop/R&B sound that isn't too distracting to listen to while working. I also really liked Eddie Vedder's new solo album, as well as many new releases by artists that didn't make it onto this top ten list (notably The Mysterines, Broken Bells, Laufey, and Mint Green).

2022 picks

Favourite book: Antkind by Charlie Kaufman

Favourite album: Endless Rooms by Rolling Blackouts Coastal Fever

Favourite film: Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022)

All data comes from GoodReads, Last.fm (when it works), and Letterboxd.

content.html:
I really liked this article I recently read by Julian Shapiro on becoming an expert, although it's more about the creative process and how to get out of your own way when it comes to doing creative work. In it, he says:

No creator was born making hits. It’s delusional to think you’re the exception. Therefore, any time you're unable to start because you think you have high quality standards that you won't be able to meet, you're lying to yourself. You're actually too lazy to discard bad work along the way in order to arrive at greatness. Take comfort in knowing that when you discard bad work via a good process, the work was not for nothing—it was to improve the process.

content.html:
I don't think I've ever given up on a book as quickly as I did with this one. A more generous reader might label it avant-garde; the Guardian blurb on the front says "surreal", but personally I'd go with pretentious and unfunny.

I'm a fan of Ayoade, and not just for being the best thing about The IT Crowd and a pedantic participant in Big Fat Quiz; I've followed him since Garth Marenghi, enjoyed his roles in The Mighty Boosh and Nathan Barley, and watched and enjoyed Submarine and The Double. I even own a copy of AD/BC, the Matt Berry rock opera for which Ayoade wrote the lyrics. In interviews and panel shows I've always found his humour clever and intellectual ... which is why this book is such a massive disappointment. I can only imagine the publishers told him that what his audience really wanted was something written in the style of Maurice Moss, but there wasn't enough material for an I, Partridge style fake autobiography so instead we got this jumbled and confusing mess - not enough fact to make it autobiographical, not even fiction to truly be parody, it's just a painful read that could have been so much more.

content.html:
One thing I'm not sure about how to handle on this site is the relative heading levels of, well, headings -- specifically when displaying an article on the site home page compared to on its own individual page.

On the home page, the natural choice for the page's top-level (H1) heading would be the site name, and so logically the list of posts would use second-level (H2) headings for their titles, and then H3 for any sub-headings. However, on the individual post page, everything needs to be hoisted up a level; the post title becomes the H1, sub-headings become H2s, and so on.

Unfortunately, since the post data is stored in a database as Markdown-formatted text, changing the heading levels on the fly based on a post's display context is not possible, at least not easily (okay, it can be done, but it would involve some kind of find-and-replace to 'fix' the heading levels in one or other of the templates).

The alternative is to sidestep the problem entirely, by simply not showing the post content on the homepage and instead adding a "description" column to the Posts table in the database. This comes with the additional benefit of then having content available that can be used in other places, for example the OpenGraph meta tags needed to make Facebook or Twitter embeds work. I think I'll go with this solution; I can see too many unexpected edge cases cropping up with the alternative.

(If I'd added tagging yet, this would be tagged with accessibility.)

content.html:
In drawing up a list of potential functionality for a new blog platform, it's tempting to tell yourself that you're going to avoid simply copying how WordPress does it. Yet, as soon as you come to start listing out features you'd like to have, it does start to read a little like the WP sidebar.

Commenting. Tagging. Categories. Search. Asset management. Statistics. Featured images. And a cool inline editor. Did blogs always need to have these things, or did WordPress redefine how we conceive of a modern blog? I did use Blogger, back in the day, but I don't really remember how it worked or whether it had any of the things we now consider essential.

Of course, you could argue that few of the things I listed are actually essential. Just write, right? Strip it back to basics. You don't need categories or tags, and allowing comments is literally the worst idea -- just look at YouTube.

But I have ideas about how I want the front-end to work, and it needs those things, so ... we're going with at least some of the WordPress feature set. At least it won't look the same.

content.html:
When I was younger, I would "reboot" my personal weblog all the time. A new design was enough to declare it rebooted; eventually we even held an international Reboot Day, back when web design was still relatively exciting and it occasionally felt as if you were doing something new and remarkable by using a particular technique.

Nowadays, of course, blogs and blogging are simultaneously dying out yet somehow ubiquitous. Every business publication, content platform, game studio, movie production and national newspaper has a blog now, and yet the advent of sites like Twitter, Medium and Substack mean that an ever-dwindling number of individuals with opinions to share choose to do so on their own personal website. Is RSS even a thing any more? Who knows. So many sites I used to read are now dead or domain-squatted, and of those that still remain online, the majority serve up a most recent entry dated several years in the past.

Did we all simply lose interest? I know I definitely don't care about web stuff as much as I used to. Content aggregators like Smashing Magazine have made it impossible to discover anything new, browser CSS doesn't need hacking any more, and design systems have made creativity an optional extra. Plus I got old, and nothing seems as important as it used to.

However, what I find that I do miss is building things, solving problems and making shit work. I don't get to do much coding at work these days and I miss it -- so I've decided that to keep myself entertained I'm going to build a new blog engine for myself. At one point it was a bit of a cliché that any developer would eventually decide (and inevitably fail) to build a new blogging platform; I'm not sure if that's still the joke but, regardless, I think it might be a fun way to stretch old muscles and learn new concepts. I'm using Laravel because that's what I'm most comfortable with; when I reach the stage of developing the front-end I'll decide whether or not to make use of anything else like React. (I suspect I won't, I'd like to keep things as simple as possible.)

And, therefore, I'm going to be dogfooding the development as I go by returning to regular blogging on this site. It's not the first time, but I only managed to write a single post on here in the last eight months, with only four in the whole of 2021. I feel like maybe two-and-a-half years of living with Covid had knocked the creativity out of me ... but now I'm ready to return.

When I was younger, I would "reboot" my personal weblog all the time. A new design was enough to declare it rebooted; eventually we even held an international Reboot Day, back when web design was still relatively exciting and it occasionally felt as if you were doing something new and remarkable by using a particular technique.
Nowadays, of course, blogs and blogging are simultaneously dying out yet somehow ubiquitous. Every business publication, content platform, game studio, movie production and national newspaper has a blog now, and yet the advent of sites like Twitter, Medium and Substack mean that an ever-dwindling number of individuals with opinions to share choose to do so on their own personal website. Is RSS even a thing any more? Who knows. So many sites I used to read are now dead or domain-squatted, and of those that still remain online, the majority serve up a most recent entry dated several years in the past.
